questions.text: In a completely and adequately immunized child against Diphtheria, the throat swab was collected. It showed the presence of following organism (shown in image) what is the staining protocol for the following image.
questions.solution:
The given case looks like Diphtheria. Image shows presence of gram positive bacilli. But C diphtheriae are best stained by Albert stain. This stain specifically stains them green colour and shows metachromatic granules. Acid fast stain is used for M tuberculosis, M leprae or cryptospora or Cyclospora.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A] Gram Stain (Incorrect)
    • diphtheriae is a Gram-positive bacillus but Gram stain does not highlight metachromatic granules, which are key to identification.
  • Choice B] Acid-Fast Stain (Incorrect)
    • Used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium leprae, and some protozoa (e.g., Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora).
    • diphtheriae is not acid-fast and does not require this staining.
  • Choice D] None (Incorrect)
    • Albert stain is the correct and specific staining method for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Key Takeaways:

  • Albert stain is the preferred method for identifying diphtheriae.
  • It stains bacilli green and metachromatic granules bluish-black.
  • Gram stain confirms Gram-positive bacilli but does not highlight granules.
  • Acid-fast stain is irrelevant as C. diphtheriae is not acid-fast.

questions.text: What is the basis of Paul Bunnel test for EBV
questions.solution:
EBV is a double stranded DNA virus. It is classified under herpes viruses.  It can cause infectious mononucleosis and Nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Symptoms of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma are a lump in the neck that does not go away in 3 weeks. Hearing loss, tinnitus, nose bleed, headache etc.

EBV Symptoms initially are fatigue, fever, inflamed throat, swollen lymph nodes in neck, enlarged spleen, swollen liver, rash. EBV affects a person's blood and bone marrow. The virus causes the body to produce an excessive number of WBCs, especially lymphocytes. EBV also decreased immune system so it makes body even weak to fight with all pathogens.

Other malignancies associated with EBV are Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin disease

The Paul Bunnell test is used for diagnosis of EBV. It works on principle of

Heterophile antibody. It Is based on the principle of presence of sheep agglutinin in the sera of infectious mononucleosis. Which are absorbed on OX ready cells but not by guinea pig kidney extract. It is performed to confirm infectious mono nucleosis and also during treatment and after treatment

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice B Cell-Mediated Hypersensitivity (Incorrect)
    • EBV primarily triggers a humoral immune response, not a cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction(Type IV hypersensitivity).
    • Cell-mediated immunity does play a role in controlling EBV infection, but it is not the basis of the Paul-Bunnell test.
  • Choice C Immune Complex Mediated (Incorrect)
    • Immune complex-mediated reactions (Type III hypersensitivity) involve antigen-antibody complexes depositing in tissues (e.g., lupus, serum sickness), but this is not the mechanism of EBV detection in the Paul-Bunnell test.
  • Choice D None (Incorrect)
    • The test is specifically based on heterophile antibodies, so this option is incorrect.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Paul-Bunnell test detects heterophile antibodies produced in response to EBV infection.
  • Heterophile antibodies cause agglutination of sheep RBCs but are not absorbed by guinea pig kidney extract.
  • The test helps in diagnosing infectious mononucleosis caused by EBV.
  • EBV is linked to nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Burkitt lymphoma, and Hodgkin disease.

choices.text: Taenia , Hymenolepis nana , Hookworm , Round worm
Hymenolepis nana , Taenia, Round worm, Hookworm
Hookworm , Taenia , Round worm , Hymenolepis nana
Round worm , Hymenolepis nana , Hookworm , Taenia

questions.text: Match the following eggs
questions.solution:
Taenia (Tapeworm) Egg

  • Appearance: Spherical, thick-shelled with radial striations.
  • Special Feature: Contains an oncosphere (hexacanth embryo)
  • Common Species: Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) and Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm).

2. Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf Tapeworm) Egg

  • Appearance: Oval, thin outer shell, with polar filaments inside.
  • Special Feature: Oncosphere is surrounded by two membranes, with filaments emerging from the inner membrane.

3. Hookworm Egg (Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus)

  • Appearance: Oval or elliptical, thin shell, blastomeres visible inside.
  • Special Feature: Clear space between shell and developing embryo.

4. Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides) Egg

  • Appearance: Thick-shelled, mammillated (bumpy) outer layer.
  • Special Feature: Can be fertilized or unfertilized; fertilized eggs are round and golden-brown, while unfertilized ones are elongated.

Key Takeaways:

  • Taenia eggs have radial striations and thick shells.
  • Hymenolepis nana eggs have polar filaments inside a thin shell.
  • Hookworm eggs are oval with blastomeres inside.
  • Ascaris (roundworm) eggs have a thick, bumpy outer shell.

questions.text: A forest worker/Rose gardener got a thorn prick which later developed with linear lesions and lymphatic spread. What will be the correct diagnosis
questions.solution:
Sporothrixschenckii is dimorphic fungus. It is naturally found in soil, hay, sphagnum moss and plants. It usually affects farmers, gardeners and agricultural workers. It affects skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is also known as rose thorn or rose gardener's disease. In cutaneous form, it forms nodular lesions or bumps in the skin at the point of entry and also along lymph nodes and vessels. Lesion starts as a painless nodule and ranges in colour from pink to purple.

 If untreated lesions become larger and look similar to a boil and more lesions will appear until a chronic ulcer develops. It occurs in fingers, hands and arms.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

  • Choice A: Insect Bite
    • Insect bites cause localized swelling, erythema, and itching.
    • They do not present with nodular lymphatic spread seen in Sporotrichosis.
  • Choice B: Mycetoma
    • Mycetoma is a chronic, deep fungal or bacterial infection.
    • It presents with granulomas, draining sinuses, and discharging granules, not linear nodular lesions along lymphatics.
  • Choice D: Scabies
    • Scabies is caused by Sarcoptes scabieiand presents with intensely pruritic papules, burrows, and crusting lesions in intertriginous areas.
    • It does not cause subcutaneous nodules or lymphatic spread.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sporotrichosis presents with nodular lesions that spread along lymphatics (lymphocutaneous spread).
  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, commonly found in soil and plants.
  • Common in gardeners, farmers, and florists.
  • Treated with Itraconazole in most cases.

questions.text: A woman presented with complaints of greenish discharge , on examination she had strawberry cervix and vagina, what will be the correct DOC for the infection.
questions.solution:
The case is of T. vaginalis. It is a sexually transmitted infection.

Risk factors are multiple sexual partners, and not using condom for intercourse or any other barrier methods.

Clinical features - foul smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching and painful urination in woe. On examination the cervix may look like strawberry cervix.

Men typically have no symptoms. Or only discharge from penis.

It is an easily treatable condition. Both partners to be treated for this condition.

Risk in pregnancy , it can cause pre mature delivery.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice B (Ceftriaxone): Ceftriaxone is used for gonorrhea, a bacterial STI caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It does not cover Trichomonas vaginalis, which is a protozoan infection.

Choice C (Doxycycline): Doxycycline is commonly used for Chlamydia trachomatis infections. It is not effective against Trichomonas vaginalis.

Choice D (Acyclovir): Acyclovir is an antiviral drug used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections. It has no role in the treatment of Trichomonas vaginalis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted protozoal infection.
  • Characteristic features include greenish vaginal discharge and strawberry cervix.
  • Metronidazole or Tinidazole is the drug of choice.
  • Both partners must be treated to prevent reinfection.

questions.text: Identify the image
questions.solution:
Doderlein bacilli are gram positive bacilli that form a microbiome, reproduce in the female vagina after gaining sexual maturity. Secrete lactic acid, and prevent the growth of other vaginitis - causing bacteria. Doderlein bacilli are part of normal flora of vagina, Lactic acid secreted by this bacteria stops the growth of other bacteria. This bacteria establishes after 2 to 8 weeks after birth.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (Mycobacterium tuberculosis - MTB): Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an acid-fast bacillus (AFB), which does not form part of the normal vaginal flora. It is the causative agent of tuberculosis and is detected using Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

Choice B (Corynebacterium diphtheriae): C. diphtheriae is a gram-positive bacillus responsible for diphtheria. It is best identified using Albert stain, which highlights its metachromatic granules.

Choice C (Gardnerella vaginalis): G. vaginalis is a gram-variable coccobacillus associated with bacterial vaginosis (BV). It is identified on clue cells in wet mount microscopy and by the whiff test (fishy odor with KOH).

Key Takeaways:

  • Döderlein bacilli (Lactobacillus species) are part of the normal vaginal microbiota.
  • They help maintain a low pH, preventing infections like bacterial vaginosis.
  • Lactic acid secretion by Döderlein bacilli inhibits the growth of pathogenic bacteria.

Cladophialophora bantiana is a dematiaceous fungus known to cause brain abscesses in human. It is one of the most common causes of invasive phaeohyphomycosis in humans. Cladophialophora bantiana is a member of the phylum ascomycota and has been isolated from soil samples from round the world. It has 70 % mortality rate despite advances in surgical resection capabilities and the use of both systemic and intrathecal antifungal treatments.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (Aspergillus niger): Aspergillus niger is a filamentous fungus commonly found in the environment. It is not dematiaceous but can cause infections like aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

Choice B (Mucor): Mucor belongs to the Mucorales order and is a non-septate, ribbon-like fungus that causes mucormycosis (a rapidly progressing fungal infection), particularly in diabetic and immunocompromised patients. It is not a dematiaceous fungus.

Choice D (Blastomyces dermatitidis): Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus responsible for blastomycosis, a pulmonary and systemic fungal infection. It is not a dematiaceous fungus and does not cause CNS infections like Cladophialophora bantiana.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cladophialophora bantianais a dematiaceous (black) fungus known for causing CNS infections (brain abscesses).
  • It is a leading cause of phaeohyphomycosis, a severe opportunistic fungal infection.
  • Has a high mortality rate (~70%), even with aggressive treatment.

Anaerobes are of many types.

Obligate anaerobes are:

  1. Bacteroides fragilis
  2. Clostridium perfringens
  3. Clostridium tetani
  4. Fusobacterium nucleatum
  5. Clostridium nucleatum
  6. Clostridium sporogenes
  7. Facultative anaerobes are
  8. E coli
  9. S aureus
  10. Gr A streptococci
  11. S epidermidis
  12. Listeria monocytogenes

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (Burkholderia cepacia):
Burkholderia cepacia is an aerobic, Gram-negative bacillus. It is an opportunistic pathogen, particularly affecting individuals with cystic fibrosis. It is not an obligate anaerobe.

Choice B (Stenotrophomonas maltophilia):
Stenotrophomonas maltophilia is a strict aerobe, meaning it requires oxygen to grow. It is a multidrug-resistant, nosocomial pathogen commonly found in hospital settings, causing pneumonia and bloodstream infections.

Choice C (Yersinia enterocolitica):
Yersinia enterocolitica is a facultative anaerobe, meaning it can grow in both the presence and absence of oxygen. It is associated with foodborne infections, causing gastroenteritis and mesenteric lymphadenitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Obligate anaerobes cannot survive in the presence of oxygen.
  • Prevotella is an obligate anaerobe commonly found in mucosal surfaces and associated with polymicrobial infections.
  • Other obligate anaerobes include:
    • Bacteroides fragilis
    • Clostridium perfringens
    • Clostridium tetani
    • Fusobacterium nucleatum

choices.text: Inhibits viral entry into host cells
Acts as an RNA polymerase inhibitor, leading to premature termination of RNA synthesis

questions.solution:
Remdesivir is a nucleotide analog prodrug that targets RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp). It is incorporated into the growing viral RNA chain, leading to the addition of three more nucleotides before the RNA synthesis stalls. This premature termination inhibits further viral replication. Remdesivir was originally developed for Ebola but was later repurposed for SARS-CoV-2 due to its effectiveness against coronaviruses.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (Inhibits viral entry into host cells): This describes the mechanism of drugs like Enfuvirtide (HIV fusion inhibitor) and Maraviroc (CCR5 antagonist), which prevent viral entry into human cells. Remdesivir does not act at this stage of infection.

Choice B (Inhibits viral protease activity): Protease inhibitors like Lopinavir and Ritonavir work by blocking viral proteases, which are essential for processing viral polyproteins into functional proteins. Remdesivir does not target proteases.

Choice D (Inhibits viral neuraminidase): This is the mechanism of Oseltamivir (Tamiflu) and Zanamivir, which block neuraminidase, preventing the release of new influenza virus particles from infected cells. Remdesivir does not act on neuraminidase.

Key Takeaways:

  • Remdesivir is an RNA polymerase inhibitor that causes premature termination of viral RNA synthesis.
  • It is incorporated into the viral RNA, preventing further elongation.
  • Initially developed for Ebola, it was later used for COVID-19
  • It does not inhibit viral entry, protease activity, or neuraminidase function.

questions.text: Hepatitis B subunit vaccine is derived from which antigen
questions.solution:
HBV contains two different antigenic components

  1. Common group reactive antigen a
  2. Two pairs of type specific antigen d-y and w-r only one member of each pair being present at a time.

HBV can be divided into four major antigenic types.

  1. Adw
  2. Adr
  3. Ayw
  4. Ayr

For vaccine production HBsAg antigen is used. It starts antibody production after vaccine as this antigen is highly immunogenic.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (HBeAg): HBeAg (Hepatitis B e-antigen) is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is not used in vaccine production as it does not induce protective immunity.

Choice C (HBcAg): HBcAg (Hepatitis B core antigen) is an internal antigen of HBV and does not circulate freely in the blood. It primarily stimulates cell-mediated immunity but does not induce protective antibodies, making it unsuitable for vaccine production.

Choice D (HBV DNA): HBV DNA is the genetic material of the virus and is used for diagnostic purposes (e.g., PCR testing for HBV viral load). It is not used in vaccines.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine derived from HBsAg, which induces protective immunity.
  • HBsAg is highly immunogenic and stimulates the production of anti-HBs antibodies, conferring immunity.
  • The vaccine is produced using recombinant DNA technologyin yeast or mammalian cell cultures.
  • HBeAg, HBcAg, and HBV DNA are not used in vaccine production.

questions.text: Most common ocular manifestations in COVID -19
questions.solution:
COVID was respiratory disease. It was causing bilateral pneumonia. Patient were having difficulty in breathing. Spo2 was going down. Pt was experiencing shortness of breath, difficulty breathing. Fatigue. Loss of taste or smell. Muscle ache, chills, sore throat, chest pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.rash

Cytokine storm was occurring in patients.

Apart from lung other organs were involved are eyes. Pt were having red eye that is conjunctivitis. Most common ocular manifestation of COVID 19 was Follicular conjunctivitis.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (Pseudomembrane conjunctivitis): Pseudomembrane conjunctivitis is a severe form of conjunctivitis where exudates form a pseudomembrane over the conjunctiva. While it has been reported in COVID-19, it is less common than follicular conjunctivitis.

Choice C (Retinal vein occlusion): Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is associated with hypercoagulability and vascular damage seen in severe COVID-19 cases. However, it is a rare ocular complication rather than the most common manifestation.

Choice D (Keratoconjunctivitis): Keratoconjunctivitis, characterized by inflammation of both the cornea and conjunctiva, has been observed in some COVID-19 cases but is not as frequent as follicular conjunctivitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19, presenting with red eyes, tearing, and mild irritation.
  • COVID-19 can involve multiple organs, including the eyes, due to cytokine stormand direct viral entry via the ocular surface.
  • Other ocular complications (e.g., pseudomembrane conjunctivitis, RVO, and keratoconjunctivitis) have been reported but are less common.

questions.text: A patient from Bihar with hypopigmented and normal aesthetic patches on the back (image given). He gave history of long term fever in his child hood. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PKDL, Post kala azar dermal leishmaniasis is a complication of visceral leishmaniasis ( VL) it is characterized by a macular, maculo popular and nodular rash in a patient who has recovered from VL and who is otherwise well. The rash usually starts around the mouth from where it spreads to tother parts of body depending on severity it is mainly seen in sudan and india where it follows treated VL in 50 % and 5-10 % cases.

It is largely restricted to areas where L donovani is main parasite causing VL. The interval at PKDL follows VL is 0-6 months in sudan and 2-3 years in india.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (Tuberculoid leprosy): Tuberculoid leprosy presents with hypopigmented, anesthetic patches with well-defined borders and nerve thickening. However, the patient's history of childhood fever and endemic location (Bihar) suggest PKDL rather than leprosy.

Choice B (Intermediate leprosy): Intermediate leprosy (Indeterminate leprosy) is an early stage of leprosy with a single or few hypopigmented patches. These lesions may progress to tuberculoid or lepromatous leprosy. PKDL, however, presents with multiple patches and is linked to past visceral leishmaniasis rather than nerve involvement.

Choice C (Lepromatous leprosy): Lepromatous leprosy presents with multiple shiny nodules, diffuse infiltration of skin, and loss of eyebrows (madarosis). The patches in PKDL are normoaesthetic, whereas lepromatous leprosy has widespread involvement and sensory loss.

Key Takeaways:

  • PKDL is a skin complication of Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-Azar).
  • It is endemic in India (Bihar, West Bengal) and Sudan, mainly caused by Leishmania donovani.
  • It follows treated VL, appearing 2-3 years later in India and 0-6 months in Sudan.
  • Lesions are hypopigmented and normoaesthetic, differentiating it from leprosy.

questions.text: A man was stung by honey bee, he was given norepinephrine, immunoglobulin responsible is
questions.solution:
Honey bee bite starts hypersensitivity Type I. Mechanism of this hypersensitivity is in sensitization phase and late phase response. In this hyper sensitivity IgE and Mast cells are important. After first exposure of antigen the helper T cells work as antigen presentation and B cells will form IgE. These antibodies will bind to mast cells and Basophils.

When the same antigen comes, Mast cell degradation occurs and patients will have smooth muscle spasm, increase mucus secretion from epithelial cells, vasodilation, increase vascular permeability, recruitment of inflammatory cells.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (IgA): IgA is primarily involved in mucosal immunity (e.g., in saliva, tears, and gut secretions). It does not mediate Type I hypersensitivity.

Choice C (IgG): IgG is the most abundant antibody in circulation and plays a role in Type II and Type III hypersensitivity reactions. It is not responsible for immediate hypersensitivity reactions.

Choice D (IgM): IgM is the first antibody produced in response to infection. It is not involved in allergic reactions or mast cell degranulation.

Key Takeaways:

  • IgE mediates Type I hypersensitivity seen in bee sting reactions.
  • Mast cell degranulation leads to histamine release, causing symptoms like bronchospasm, vasodilation, and anaphylaxis.
  • Epinephrine is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis.

questions.text: 2 week old baby had conjunctivitis, on examination of CXR showed pneumonia, probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis can cause congenital infection of the eye. In the case pt is 2 week old, has conjunctivitis and pneumonia both.

It also causes trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum, non gono coccal urethritis, cervicitis, salpingitis, pelvic inflammatory disease.

It is one of common STDs

If untreated , chlamydia cause pelvic inflammatory disease in women, which can lead to chronic pain and infertility in me, untreated chlamydia causes pain and swelling in one or both testicles.

Antibiotic therapy for the affected patient and the sexual partners of patients is recommended. Doxycycline and azithromycin are used for treatment.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice A (H. influenzae): H. influenzae is a common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in older children but does not typically cause neonatal pneumonia.

Choice B (Mycoplasma):

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes atypical pneumonia in older children and adults but does not cause neonatal conjunctivitis.

Choice C (S. agalactiae):

  • Group B Streptococcus (GBS) can cause early-onset neonatal sepsis and pneumonia but does not cause conjunctivitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of neonatal conjunctivitis (5-14 days after birth) and pneumonia.
  • CXR findings include interstitial infiltrates ("diffuse pneumonia").
  • Treated with oral macrolides (azithromycin or erythromycin).
  • Screening and treatment of pregnant women prevent transmission.

questions.text: Attachment and effacement pathogenesis
questions.solution:
Attachment and effacement occurs in Enteropathogenic E coli.

E coli has many subtypes, Enteroinvasive E coli, Entero aggregative E coli. Enterohemorrhagic E coli.

All have different mechanism. Main pathogenesis of EPEC is attachment and effacement. It causes diarrhea in infants and children usually occurs as institutional outbreak.

It does not produce enterotoxin nor they are invasive. They adhere to the mucosa of small intestine and cause disruption of brush border microvilli.

Enterotoxigenic E coli - it causes travellers diarrhea. It produce enterotoxin

Enteroinvasive E coli resemble shigella and their infection resembles shigellosis

Enterohemorrhagic E coli - produce verocytotoxin or shiga like toxin. They can cause hemorrhagic colitis.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice B (EIEC - Enteroinvasive E. coli):

  • Pathogenesis is similar to Shigella and involves direct invasion of the intestinal epithelium, leading to bloody diarrhea (dysentery-like illness).
  • Does not cause attachment and effacement.

Choice C (EAEC - Enteroaggregative E. coli):

  • EAEC is characterized by biofilm formation and persistent diarrhea, especially in HIV patients and malnourished children.
  • It does not cause attachment and effacement but instead adheres in a "stacked-brick" pattern to the intestinal epithelium.

Choice D (None of the above):

  • Incorrect, as EPEC is the correct answer.

Key Takeaways:

  • EPEC is the only E. coli subtype that causes "attachment and effacement" lesions.
  • Leads to watery diarrhea, mostly in infants and children.
  • Does not produce toxins or invade intestinal cells.
  • Other E. coli types (ETEC, EIEC, EAEC, EHEC) have different mechanisms of pathogenesis.

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method where a lab-raised, disease-free vector (insect) is allowed to feed on a suspected infected individual, and later, the vector is examined for the presence of the pathogen.

  • This method is commonly used for detecting Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease.
  • The vector used is usually the reduviid bug (kissing bug).
  • After feeding on the patient, the bug's gut is examined for the presence of T. cruzi.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice B (Trypanosoma brucei):

  • Causes African Sleeping Sickness, transmitted by the tsetse fly.
  • Diagnosis is usually done by blood smear, CSF examination, or serology, not xenodiagnosis.

Choice C (Plasmodia - Malaria parasites):

  • Diagnosis of malaria is done via peripheral blood smear, rapid antigen tests, or PCR.
  • Xenodiagnosis is not used for malaria.

Choice D (None of the above):

  • Incorrect, as T. cruzi is diagnosed by xenodiagnosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Xenodiagnosis is mainly used for Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease).
  • Involves allowing a lab-raised vector (reduviid bug) to feed on the patient, then examining the bug for the parasite.
  • Not used for T. brucei or Plasmodium species.

questions.text: Pasteurization test done for milk is done by all except
questions.solution:
To test pasteurization One common test is done. Alkaline phosphatase test, it is an indicator of adequate pasteurization of milk and cream. A proprietary fluorometric technique is a sensitive and quantitative method for the determination of alkaline phosphatase activity in milk products. Other tests is methylene blue reduction test. And Standard plate count. Coliform count method is used for water testing .

Pasteurization is the process of heating milk to destroy pathogenic microorganisms while preserving its quality. Various tests are performed to ensure effective pasteurization, including:

  • Choice A: Alkaline Phosphatase Test:
    • Detects residual alkaline phosphatase, an enzyme naturally present in raw milk but destroyed by pasteurization.
    • If alkaline phosphatase is present, it indicates incomplete pasteurization.
  • Choice B: Standard Plate Count (SPC):
    • Determines the total bacterial load in milk after pasteurization.
    • It is a general indicator of hygienic quality.
  • Choice C : Methylene Blue Reduction Test (MBRT):
    • Measures the oxygen consumption by bacteria in milk.
    • Faster decolorization means higher bacterial load, indicating poor milk quality.

Key Takeaways:

  • Alkaline Phosphatase Test, Standard Plate Count, and Methylene Blue Reduction Test are used to assess pasteurization.
  • Coliform Count is mainly used for water testing, not for evaluating pasteurization efficiency.

questions.text: Identify the disease in image
questions.solution:
Varicella ( chicken pox) and herpes zoster are different manifestations of the same virus infection. The virus is therefore called varicella zoster virus.

Primary infection causes chickenpox

Reactivation of latent VZV, when immunity has fallen to ineffective levels, causes herpes zoster.
The virus remains dormant in the sensory ganglion of the trigeminal nerve and reaches the eye along one or more branches of the ophthalmic division of 5th nerve.
Herpes zoster

Occurs in old age

Dermatomes from T3 to L3 and trigeminal nerves are involved.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Choice B (Impetigo):

  • Caused by: Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Lesions: Honey-colored crusted pustules, mostly in children.
  • Highly contagious but non-vesicular.

Choice C (Syphilis - Chancre):

  • Caused by: Treponema pallidum (a spirochete).
  • Primary syphilis lesion: Painless, clean-based ulcer (chancre) at the site of infection.
  • Heals spontaneously in 3-6 weeks without treatment.

Choice D (Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease - HFMD):

  • Caused by: Coxsackievirus A16 or Enterovirus 71.
  • Lesions: Vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and oral mucosa, often in children.
  • Associated symptoms: Fever, sore throat, and malaise.

Key Takeaways:

  • Herpes presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, which rupture to form painful ulcers.
  • Tzanck smear helps in diagnosis (multinucleated giant cells).
  • It differs from Impetigo (honey-colored crusts), Syphilis (painless ulcer), and HFMD (vesicles on hands, feet, and mouth).

questions.text: Hepatitis B is which type of virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Hepatitis B virus is the most wide spread virus and the most important cause of viral hepatitis.
HBV belongs to Hepadna viridae

HBV is hepadnavirus type 1

Hepatitis B is the only hepatitis virus which has DNA. All other are RNA viruses

HBV contains two linear strand of DNA. One of the strands is incomplete nd other is complete - Partially double stranded DNA.

HBV contains both DNA - dependent DNA polymerase and RNA dependent reverse transcriptase

Instead of DNA replication directly from DNA template, HBV relys on reverse transcriptase of minus strand DNA from A pregenomic RNA intermediate ( Like retrovirus).

Incorrect Options:

  • RNA (Choice B): HBV is a DNA virus, whereas hepatitis A, C, D, E, and G are RNA viruses.
  • Both DNA and RNA (Choice C): HBV has only DNA, not both nucleic acids.
  • None of the above (Choice D): Incorrect, as HBV is definitively a DNA virus.

Key Takeaways:

  • HBV is the only DNA hepatitis virus.
  • It replicates through an RNA intermediate using reverse transcriptase.
  • It belongs to the Hepadnaviridae family.
